description:
Fundulus diaphanus, commonly known as the banded killifish, is a small freshwater fish species native to eastern North America. It belongs to the family Fundulidae, which is a group of killifishes.

The banded killifish is a small, slender fish typically reaching lengths of around 5-8 cm (2-3 inches). It is characterized by its distinct banding pattern, which consists of 12-15 dark vertical bars along its sides. The fish's body is greenish-brown or olive-colored on the back, fading to a lighter, silvery-white color on the belly.

Fundulus diaphanus is found in a variety of freshwater habitats, including ponds, lakes, slow-moving streams, and estuaries. It prefers areas with aquatic vegetation and sandy or gravelly substrates. The banded killifish is an omnivorous species, feeding on a diet that includes small invertebrates, algae, and plant material.

Reproduction in Fundulus diaphanus involves external fertilization, with the females laying their eggs among aquatic plants or on submerged surfaces. The eggs hatch after a period of several days, and the young killifish undergo a larval stage before developing into adults.

The banded killifish is an ecologically important species, serving as a food source for larger predatory fish and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the freshwater ecosystems it inhabits.
